abstracts.cdata!:
The Selebi-Phikwe Technical Assistant
            Project in Botswana was achieved. The Bank's
            performance in project identification, preparation and
            appraisal was highly satisfactory. The Bank took an active
            role in advising the Government that the project should not
            only deal with immediate emergency issues, but also with the
            medium to long-term prospects of making the transition from
            mining to other activities in Selebi-Phikwe feasible. The
            Government's performance in project identification,
            preparation, and appraisal was satisfactory. The key lessons
            learned from the implementation of the project are: to
            effectively monitor completion of any activity, clear
            performance targets need to be set at appraisal; to assess
            the success or failure of any program, the expected output
            need to be established at project appraisal; recommendations
            made by project evaluation study should be evaluated and the
            relevant recommendations taken into consideration in order
            to correct any impediment to project implementation and
            sustainability; and Government's full commitment is a
            key element in the successful implementation and
            sustainability of any project component.
